awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Deciphering Brain Function Through Dynamic Sparse Signal Processing
awd_abstract_narration:
The ability to adapt to changes in the environment and to optimize performance against undesirable stimuli is among the hallmarks of the brain function. Capturing the adaptivity and robustness of brain function in real-time is crucial not only for deciphering its underlying mechanisms, but also for designing neural prostheses and brain-computer interface devices with adaptive and robust performance.  Thanks to the advances in neural data acquisition technology, the process of data collection has been substantially facilitated, resulting in abundant pools of high-dimensional, dynamic, and complex data under various modalities and conditions from the nervous systems of animals and humans. The current modeling paradigm and estimation algorithms, however, face challenges in processing these data due to their ever-growing dimensions. This research addresses these challenges by providing a unified framework to efficiently utilize the abundant pools of data in order to deliver game-changing applications in systems neuroscience.

Converging lines of evidence in theoretical and experimental neuroscience suggest that brain activity is a distributed high-dimensional spatiotemporal process emerging from sparse dynamic structures. From a computational perspective sparsity is a key ingredient in rejecting interfering signals and achieving robustness in neural computation and information representation in the brain.  The main objective therefore is to develop a mathematically principled methodology that captures the dynamicity and sparsity of neural data in a scalable fashion with high accuracy. By focusing on the auditory system as a quintessential instance of sophisticated brain function, this research investigates several fundamental questions in systems neuroscience such as plasticity, attention, and stimulus decoding. The research is integrated with education and outreach activities including high school level hands-on workshops, undergraduate capstone projects, and interdisciplinary course development.

por.por_cntn:
The ability to adapt to changes in the environment and to optimize performance against undesirable stimuli is among the hallmarks of the brain function. Capturing the adaptivity and robustness of brain function in real-time is crucial not only for deciphering its underlying mechanisms, but also for designing neural prostheses and brain-computer interface devices with adaptive and robust performance. Thanks to the advances in neural data acquisition technology, the process of data collection has been substantially facilitated, resulting in abundant pools of high-dimensional, dynamic, and complex data under various modalities and conditions from the nervous systems of animals and humans. The current modeling paradigm and estimation algorithms, however, face challenges in processing these data due to their ever-growing dimensions. This research addressed these challenges by providing a unified framework to efficiently utilize the abundant pools of data in order to deliver game-changing applications in systems neuroscience.

Converging lines of evidence in theoretical and experimental neuroscience suggest that brain activity is a distributed high-dimensional spatiotemporal process emerging from sparse dynamic structures. From a computational perspective sparsity is a key ingredient in rejecting interfering signals and achieving robustness in neural computation and information representation in the brain. The main objective of this project therefore was to develop a mathematically principled methodology that captures the dynamicity and sparsity of neural data in a scalable fashion with high accuracy. By focusing on the auditory system as a quintessential instance of sophisticated brain function, this research investigated several fundamental questions in systems neuroscience such as plasticity, attention, and neural decoding. The research was also tightly integrated with education and outreach activities including high school level hands-on workshops, undergraduate capstone projects, and interdisciplinary course development. 

The key outcomes of the project are as follows:

1) The modeling and analysis techniques resulted in the characterization of the ferret's and mouse?s cortical function under attentive auditory behavior at unprecedented spatiotemporal resolutions, revealing how neurons in the frontal and sensory cortices interact to result in robust behavior (See Image 1).

2) The Neuro-Current Response Function (NCRF) modeling paradigm for identifying the temporal response function from auditory MEG data has revealed the cortical processes that underlie acoustic, lexical, and semantic processing, with potential application in the design of smart hearing aid devices and providing quantitative neuromarkers of hearing disorders (See Image 2).

3) The dynamic Bayesian multitaper spectral analysis as well as the Point Process Multitaper Method (PMTM) have resulted in high resolution spectrogram representations of binary and non-stationary data, respectively. This framework can impact other disciplines involving such data types, including finance, geophysics, and radar data (See Image 3).

4) The Network Localized Granger Causality (NLGC) methodology has allowed to resolve age-related and task-related differences in cortical networks that underlie auditory processing at high resolutions from MEG data. Application of NLGC to MEG data from patients recovering from mild brain strokes revealed the interactions of motor vs. non-motor cortical areas as modulated by patients' recovery trajectories (See Image 4).

5) A book chapter in the Handbook of Neuroengineering (Ed. Nitish V. Thakor, Springer, 2021) highlights the new results on neural encoding and decoding resulted from the research under this project. The book chapter is expected to reach out to broad audiences in both neuroscience and engineering.

6) The PI successfully designed a two-week course module for a freshman-level course called "ENEE101 Introduction to Electrical and Computer Engineering" at the University of Maryland, which provides exposure to neural data analysis and modeling, using 3 hands-on lab sessions involving EEG recording and analysis. The PI is in the process of translating this module to a high school-?level workshop, with the aim of providing high school students with early exposure to brain research, and encouraging them to consider careers in STEM?-related fields.

  • Adaptive Granger Causality (AGC) analysis of single neurons in ferret frontal and auditory cortices during attentive auditory task reveals the fine-scale interaction and dynamics of neurons. A. Spike trains, B. Inferred AGC results, C. Functional networks from AGC, D. Task-dependent plasticity.
    Alireza Sheikhattar, Sina Miran, Ji Liu, Jonathan B. Fritz, Shihab A. Shamma, Patrick O. Kanold, and Behtash Babadi
    Copyrighted

    Adaptive Granger Causality Analysis
  • Dynamic Bayesian Multitaper Spectral Analysis (DBMT) allows to obtain denoised spectrogram representations of non-stationary and complex time-series data. A. Spectrograms obtained by conventional methods. B. Spectrograms obtained by DBMT and log-DBMT are significantly denoised.
    Proloy Das and Behtash Babadi
    Copyrighted
    Behtash Babadi
    Dynamic Bayesian Multitaper Spectral Analysis
  • Neuro-Current Response Functions (NCRFs) form a system model of how cortical activity encodes acoustic information at the whole-brain level, and can be estimated from magnetoencephalography data recorded from the human brain. A. The anatomical plots of NCRFs, B. Selected time courses of 6 NCRFs.
    Proloy Das, Christian Brodbeck, Jonathan Z. Simon, and Behtash Babadi
    Copyrighted
    Behtash Babadi
    Neuro-Current Response Functions
  • Network Localized Granger Causality (NLGC) localizes directional connectivity directly from MEG data, instead of first localizing sources and then estimating their connectivity. NLGC analysis of MEG data in the 0.1�8 Hz frequency band reveals cortical effects of healthy aging and task condition.
    Behrad Soleimani, Proloy Das, I. M. Dushyanthi Karunathilake, Stefanie E. Kuchinsky, Jonathan Z. Simon, and Behtash Babadi
    Copyrighted
    Behtash Babadi
    Network Localized Granger Causality
